snippet.textDisplay: Prof Seheult, thank you for your excellent videos. I have a technical question that perhaps you or someone else can answer. I'm not too nervous about having mrna injected into me as part of a tested vaccine because mrna has a short half life and will soon be gone. But DNA is very stable and could remain in my body for years or even for the rest of my life (am I correct about this?). Will this injected DNA keep on producing spike proteins for months or even years? If not, why not? Might this cause my body to have a continuous, albeit low level, immune response to these spike proteins? It seems to me that this could have negative effects. I couldn't find anything directly addressing this by using Google search. Do you have any thoughts on this? Very respectfully, Mark.
